key_title: Key to the species of Stipa

source.author: Walsh, N.G.

leads.lead_text: Summit of lemma without corona but sometimes with a tuft of hairs (coma) at apex. Palea more than half as long as lemma (except in some Group 4 species)
Summit of lemma forming a firm, cylindric corona 0.5–2.5 mm long, terminated by a ring of erect bristles or slightly divergent spines; palea less than half as long as lemma; introduced species
Awn more than 20 mm long; cleistogenes not present; caryopsis narrow, closely enclosed within lemma; indigenous species, not or rarely forming closed swards

Awn less than 20 mm long; seed (caryopsis) plump and top-shaped, loosely enclosed within the lemma; rows of seed-like propagules (cleistogenes) borne in basal leaf-sheaths; leafy, introduced grass which may form closed swards
Lemma lacking apical lobes or lobes much less than 1 mm long; habit not as above
Lemma with acute narrow lobes more than 1 mm long at apex; prickly-leaved, tufted, maritime grass or a wiry, rhizomatous grass of heaths and woodlands
Tufted perennials or annuals; culms usually simple; nodes various; awn bristle terete or somewhat angular but not flattened
Rhizomatous perennials often lacking a basal tuft; culms often branched; nodes dark and conspicuous; awn bristle distinctly flattened or triangular in section
Awn of mature spikelets twice bent, more or less straight above the bends
Awn of mature spikelets evenly curved beyond basal, strongly twisted part
Lemma with coma at apex (coma sometimes sparse or of hairs no longer than those of body of lemma); glumes acute to acuminate
Lemma without coma at apex (except occasionally in S. rudis subsp. nervosa, which has truncate to obtuse glumes)
Glumes bulging around floret; lemma relatively stout (length mostly less than 6 times diam.); callus strongly curved, relatively short (10–25% of remainder of lemma); panicle open
Glumes not bulging around floret; lemma relatively slender (length mostly more than 6 times diam.); callus almost straight, relatively long (25–40% of remainder of lemma); panicle open or contracted
Palea flat or convex; ligule less than 4 mm long
Palea distinctly grooved down the centre; ligule 1.5–9 mm long
Coma to 2 (rarely 2.5) mm long; leaves glabrous, scabrous or very sparsely pubescent
Coma 2–5 mm long; at least the lower leaves distinctly pubescent
Ligule firm, to 1.5 mm long, ciliate; coma usually somewhat spreading; to 1.5 m high, mostly on basaltic soils
Ligule (at least of upper leaves) papery, 1–4 mm long, glabrous; coma erect; typically a tall (to 2 m) grass resembling oat (Avena spp.), mostly in northern Victoria
Awn 30–60 mm long, and bent at less than right-angles, arising centrally at apex of lemma
Awn 25–35 mm long, strongly twice bent (usually at right-angles) and arising toward dorsal side of lemma (i.e. not central at apex) due to asymmetric development of grain
Lemma more or less evenly hairy; coma 1.2 mm long or more; column of awn glabrous or scabrous with hairs less than 0.2 mm long; ligule to 0.5 mm long
Lemma almost or quite glabrous (but scabrous) about the well-defined neck; coma 0.5–1 mm long (rarely to 2 mm); column of awn usually pubescent with hairs 0.3–0.5 mm long; ligule 0.5–1.5 mm long
Lemma granular, hardly shining, the surface more or less obscured by hairs; summit of leaf-sheath without woolly hairs
Lemma smooth and shining, glabrous or very sparsely hairy; summit of leaf-sheath encircled by copious woolly hairs; rare, apparently confined to gypsum-rich rises in the far north-west

Hairs on lemma abruptly shorter near apex, creating a conspicuous dorsal ?bald patch?; elsewhere on lemma hairs dense, usually covering lemma surface, shining golden brown or coppery at maturity; mainly western species

Hairs on lemma evenly distributed (except for denser callus region), or reducing gradually toward apex of lemma (rarely with subapical ?bald patch? on dorsal surface in hairy-awned S. stuposa), sparse to moderately dense but not covering lemma surface, white to golden brown at maturity
Lower glume 14–25 mm long; lemma 6–9 mm long; widespread in dry western areas
Lower glume 8–14 mm long; lemma 4–6 mm long; rare, only in far north-west and Horsham district
Column of awn glabrous, scabrous or pubescent but hairs generally less than 0.5 mm long; coma to 1.5 mm long, often inconspicuous, the hairs not or barely longer or denser than those of lemma body
Column of awn plumose with hairs 0.5–1.5 mm long; coma 1–3 mm long, usually with hairs distinctly longer and denser than those of lemma body
Culms to 1 mm diam. at base; panicle sparse; glumes distinctly purplish (at least when young); never coastal
Culms 1–4 mm diam. at base; panicle dense; glumes pale green, less commonly purplish; near-coastal
Leaves pubescent, fine and flexuose; lower glume 8–12 mm long
Leaves glabrous (sometimes scabrous or rarely with few short, stiff hairs), rigidly erect; lower glume 12–17 mm long
Column of awn smooth or scabrous with hairs less than 0.3 mm long
Column of awn plumose or pubescent with hairs more than 0.3 mm long
Glumes acute or acuminate (if eroded at tips, then glumes more than 15 mm long)
Glumes truncate or obtuse, 8–15 mm long
Lower glume more than 16 mm long; awn 55–110 mm long, more than 20 mm to the first bend; summit of lemma granular to minutely scabrous, usually without lobes
Lower glume 11–18 mm long; awn 50–80 mm long, less than 20 mm to the first bend; summit of lemma strongly antrorsely scabrous, with 1 or 2 lobes to 0.5 mm long
Panicle sparse, usually with no more than 20 spikelets; awn 80–110 mm long, 45–60 mm to the first bend; glumes and basal leaf-sheaths strongly purplish; alpine or subalpine species

Panicle sparse or moderately dense, usually with more than 20 spikelets; awn 55–95 mm long, 25–50 mm to the first bend; glumes and basal leaf-sheaths not or only slightly purplish; lowland to foothill species
Lemma 7 mm long or more; awn 50–110 mm long
Lemma 5–7 mm long; awn 30–60 mm long
Longest hairs on column of awn 0.3–1 mm long (rarely to 1.2 mm), evenly distributed around column and not appearing to spiral
Longest hairs on column of awn at least 1 mm long, arranged mostly in a row and appearing to spiral as the awn twists

Summit of lemma strongly antrorsely scabrous, with 1 or 2 lobes to 0.5 mm long, hairs on lemma (excluding callus) often confined to dorsal nerve region and margins; inflorescence open; glumes and lower leaf-sheaths strongly purplish
Summit of lemma granular, usually without lobes, hairs on lemma not confined to dorsal nerve region and margins; inflorescence contracted; lower leaf-sheaths not or only weakly purplish
Inflorescence dense; glumes pubescent; leaves strongly pubescent; usually in rocky sites, widespread
Inflorescence loosely contracted; glumes glabrous to minutely scabrous; rather rare species of dry sandy sites in the west and goldfields
Awn less than 90 mm long; ligule less than 5 mm long; hairs, when present not appearing hollow; perennial
Awn extremely long (10–20 cm); ligule of upper leaves usually more than 5 mm long, glabrous; sheath of at least lower leaves densely covered with shining, hollow hairs; annual
Column of awn pubescent with spreading hairs 0.3–0.8 mm long; leaf-blades 2 mm or more wide but sometimes inrolled
Column of awn scabrous or with appressed to slightly spreading hairs to 0.4 mm long; leaf-blades less than 2 mm wide, usually tightly inrolled or closely folded
Leaf-blades flat or only slightly inrolled, 2–7 mm wide, densely short-pubescent; nodes usually concealed by broad, pale-margined sheaths; inflorescence dense, typically 25–40 cm long
Leaf-blades closely inrolled, pungent at apex, glabrous or pubescent but never densely so; nodes apparent, sheaths narrow and tightly enveloping culm; inflorescence slender, to 20 cm long
Leaf-blades strongly inrolled, very fine (less than 1 mm diam.), usually erect
Leaf-blades weakly or strongly inrolled, more than 1 mm diam., usually somewhat spreading
Leaf-blades scabrous, rarely sparsely pubescent with rigid hairs to c. 0.5 mm long; lower part of awn glabrous or scabrous with outgrowths less than 0.2 mm long
Leaf-blades with spreading hairs c. 1 mm long; lower part of awn pubescent with hairs 0.2–0.4 mm long
Inflorescence dense, overall light green and shining, its base usually partly enclosed by sheath of uppermost leaf when young; new shoots intravaginal
Inflorescence typically sparse, overall purplish, its base usually exserted from sheath of uppermost leaf; new shoots extravaginal
Panicle broadly pyramidal at maturity; panicle branches plumose
Panicle various; panicle branches glabrous, scabrous or minutely pubescent but never plumose
Hairs of panicle branches 1.5–3 mm long; nodes glabrous; glumes pilose on the nerves
Hairs of panicle branches 0.3–0.6 mm long; nodes pubescent; glumes scabrous on the nerves
Callus c. 1 mm long; lower glume 6–15 mm long; lemma 4.5–6 mm long
Callus c. 0.5 mm long; lower glume 5–6.5 mm long; lemma 3–4.5 mm long
Bristle triangular in section, not wider at its base than the column, nearly straight
Bristle flat, wider at its base than the column, usually strongly falcate
Panicle reduced to 1–4 spikelets; culms branched; rhizomatous grass
Panicle with more than 8 spikelets; culms simple; tufted grass with prickly leaves
Lemma more than 6 mm long, callus more than 1 mm long
Lemma 3.5–6 mm long, including callus to 1 mm long
Summit of corona ciliate, with erect hairs, 0.6–1.5 mm long at maturity; glumes 11–15 mm long; awns 35–60 mm long; inflorescence usually far exceeding leaves
Summit of corona with slightly divergent spines, 0.2–0.5 mm long at maturity; glumes 16–25 mm long; awns 60–90 mm long; inflorescence usually subequal to leaves
